title: Bryan Cranston major condition before reprising role Breaking Bad movie
text:
Bryan Cranston had one major condition before playing Breaking bad’s Walter White again (Picture: AP Photo/AMC, Frank Ockenfels )

What would a Breaking Bad movie be without good old science-teacher-turned-drug-dealer Walter White?

Well it turns out actor Bryan Cranston was only willing to return to play the beloved character in El Camino: A Breaking Bad Movie under one major condition – Walter White had to still be dead.

Fans of the series will remember the show’s protagonist, Walter, met his fateful end in the series finale where he was shot and killed in 2013.

But while the show’s creator Vince Gilligan confirmed White’s death during an interview about the movie, what the director failed to mention was that good old Walter would still be appearing in the movie in other forms.

And it seems Cranston appears to agree with the film maker, who said the series had a ‘perfect’ ending.

Speaking to Rolling Stone, the 63-year-old actor said: ‘I would say that yes, if [Breaking Bad creator Vince Gilligan] came to me and said, “Let’s do the series again. Walter White didn’t die. Let’s just say that, and then we’ll see if we can get two or three more years out of it,” that’s when I would have to say, “I don’t think we should”.’

He added: ‘What he wrote for the conclusion of the series is, to me, perfect. So I think that would be a problem if he wanted to. But I know he doesn’t.’

The actor instead was pleased to see the film, which was released on Netflix on 11 October, focus on his co-star Aaron Paul who plays his partner in crime, Jesse Pinkman.

El Camino: A Breaking Bad Movie picks right back up from where we left Jesse in series five, where the character is being hunted by law enforcement after escaping a white supremacist compound.

The movie however, still sees the return of deceased fan favorite characters such as Walter and Mike Ehrmantraut played by Jonathan Banks through a series of flashback scenes.

Bryan returns as Walter White in El Camino movie (Picture: Netflix)

In one of the dream-like moments, Walter returns alongside Jesse for a light-hearted scene in a diner before their partnership had turned sour, as Jesse mulls over the idea of going to college.

Speaking to Jesse, Walter says: ‘You’re really lucky, you know that. You didn’t have to wait your whole life to do something special.’

We’re not crying, you are.

When speaking about being asked to return to his role as Walter for the movie, Cranston said ‘wonderful’.

He explained: ‘I was really grateful that he thought of me to be a part of this. At the same time, I was wondering, “How the hell is that going to work?”

‘I guessed it only could be retrospective, in flashback, and said, “OK, whatever he has to do”.’
